Title: Corrigendum to “Young EFL learners' processing of multimodal input: Examining learners’ eye movements” [System 80C (2019) 212–223] (System (2019) 80 (212–223), (S0346251X18305153), (10.1016/j.system.2018.12.002))
Abstract: © 2018 Elsevier LtdThe authors would like to inform the readers that in the original publication of the above-mentioned paper, they have missed to notice and replace a few blinded citations both in the text as well as in the references list. The authors have provided below the unblinded citations for the benefit of the readers. On page 214, the blinded in-text reference citation “XXX, 2016” should read “Pellicer-Sánchez, A., 2016″ On page 216, the blinded in-text reference citations “XXXXX, 2016” and “XXX, 2018” should read “Conklin, K. & Pellicer-Sánchez A., 2016” and “Conklin, K., Pellicer-Sánchez A. & G. Carrol G., 2018”, respectively. Also find below the unblinded citations in the reference list: XXX. (2016). Using eye-tracking in applied linguistics and second language research. Second Language Research, 32(3), 453e467. https://doi.org/10.1177/0267658316637401 where “XXXX” should read “Conklin, K. & Pellicer-Sánchez A.” XXX. (2018). Eye-tracking: A guide for applied linguistics research. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. Where “XXX” should read “Conklin, K., Pellicer-Sánchez A. & G. Carrol G.” XXXXX. (2016). Incidental vocabulary acquisition from and while reading: An eye-tracking study. Studies in Second Language Acquisition, 38, 97e130. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0272263115000224. Where “XXXXX” should read “Pellicer-Sánchez, A.” The authors would like to apologize for the inconvenience caused.
